awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant: Burnout: The Epistemologies of a Modern Condition
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates ‘burnout’ at work as a category of experience and object of inquiry in science, organizational design, and culture. Blending insights from science and technology studies on scientific classification processes, organizational design, and knowledge workers, it asks three main research questions: What epistemic, political, and institutional changes account for shifts in the ways that burnout has been conceptualized and addressed? How do actors make claims about burnout? Why has the concept of burnout become crucial to efforts to maintain well-being within the workforce? These questions will be answered using a mixed-methods research design blending archival research, ethnography, interviews, and participant workshops to investigate three case studies: the early history of burnout research, a group who study burnout among healthcare workers, and a group of software developers experiencing burnout. Broader impacts include holding participatory workshops among stakeholders to inform them about their condition and generate knowledge about how burnout manifests in individual, interpersonal, and institutional contexts.

This project synthesizes data from multiple qualitative research methods to understand the phenomena of ‘burnout’ within the modern workplace. Data from historical archival research, ethnographic observations, and participatory focus groups are triangulated to understand the causes and consequences of burnout within the modern workforce, and how the concept of burnout has undergone cultural, political, and historical transformations. Documentary analysis of the early history of burnout research enables understanding of how the concept of burnout has changed over time. Participant observation of a university-based research group who studies burnout among healthcare workers allows for understanding of how burnout affects physicians and how interventions are developed to deal with it. Ethnographic observations among information technology workers who develop open source software facilitates deeper understanding of how workers define and deploy the notion of burnout in non-medical contexts. Taken together, this project advances the current state of knowledge about burnout in science and technology studies and social and cultural studies of work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dorothy Howard was supported in the dissertation, Burnout: The Epistemologies of a Modern Condition, supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Initiative Grant (DDRIG). Data collection has been concluded, and the dissertation is currently in the write-up stages of completion.  

As a qualitative researcher and historian, Howard aimed to investigate how organizations and other actors have adjusted institutional infrastructures in response to worker burnout and built new organizational structures to address worker mental health in response to concerns about burnout. To provide adequate background, historical investigations were conducted about how researchers in occupational science and health, as well as organizational science and management have built common understandings around diagnoses to address workplace health, and specifically medical processes of canonization leading to the emergence of the diagnosis of workplace burnout. Investigators engaged in historical research on the history of the evolving science of studying the depletion of workers? physical and psychological ?energies? in the history of American medicine, occupational science, and industrial and organizational psychology. Two qualitative, ethnographic studies were designed and conducted on organizational responses to burnout and how multiple stakeholders have engaged in organizational initiatives directed at burnout. Ethnographic research has involved participant observation, and managing the logistics of interviews, including recruiting participants, securing informed consent, conducting interviews, creating transcripts, sharing the transcripts back with participants (member checking), qualitatively coding interview transcripts, and using grounded theory to identify common themes.

Investigators engaged in ethnographic research within a public university health system about how actors have engaged in research and created networks of knowledge sharing, leadership interventions, organized as workers, and engaged in meta-discussions around affective science and public communication around the affective conditions of the workplace in relationship to organizational sustainability and economics. The findings indicate that management and workers engaged in work to reach common understandings of the science behind burnout, related workplace health conditions, existential problems within the professions of health and healing, and opportunities for internal institutional research among staff. Workers expressed an increased urgency of these themes, as research was conducted before and during the COVID-19 pandemic in a clinical health research institutional context.

Investigators also engaged in ethnography among members of open technology communities who identified as experiencing burnout, and organizational actors which have sprung to recognize and act on burnout as an organizational problem. The findings indicate that discussions about governance have emerged as a response to structural problems within free and open source software (F/OSS) communities, which have resulted in burnout among maintainers. Notably, new organizational structures within technology companies such as Open Source Program Offices (OSPOs), as well as consulting companies, community initiatives composed of stakeholders in software maintenance, and non-profit organizations have been created to respond to cultural and economic issues affecting worker burnout, tying economic success with software worker/developer mental health and wellbeing.

The dissertation contributes to Science and Technology Studies through it’s focus on organizational sense-making on a scientific diagnoses, the role of expertise in shaping organizational practice, and finds common points of interest between Science and Technology Studies, occupational health, and organizational science studies.

Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Dorothy R Howard
